meanings.definition: A structure extending alongshore or out from the shore into a body of water, to which boats may be moored.
meanings.sent1: The dock was busy with boats coming and going.
meanings.sent2: The fishermen tied their boat to the dock before unloading their catch.
meanings.sent3: The seagull perched on the dock, eyeing the fish below.
meanings.sent4: The dock stretched like a welcoming arm into the calm waters.
meanings.sent5: Children played by the dock, watching the gentle waves lap against the wooden planks.

meanings.definition: To remove or deduct a part of.
meanings.sent1: She had to dock his pay for being late to work.
meanings.sent2: The teacher had to dock points from the student's assignment for not following instructions.
meanings.sent3: The chef had to dock some ingredients from the recipe to make it work.
meanings.sent4: The tailor had to dock the fabric to make the dress fit perfectly.
meanings.sent5: The manager had to dock the budget to accommodate unexpected expenses.

meanings.definition: A place for the repair of ships.
meanings.sent1: The dock was bustling with activity as ships were being repaired.
meanings.sent2: The sailors were relieved to reach the dock after a storm damaged their ship.
meanings.sent3: The dock became a temporary home for the crew while their ship was being repaired.
meanings.sent4: The dock echoed with the sounds of hammers and saws as repairs were underway.
meanings.sent5: The dockyard workers skillfully repaired the ship, ensuring it was seaworthy once again.
